page.title: 04Clayton Hall
page.content: {Clayton Hall}is the only example of a {moated residence} remaining intact in Manchester. The present hall, which is situated in the grounds of{Clayton {Park,}is probably the second or third to occupy the site. The history of the hall dates from the{12th century}and was built on the site of a house of a branch of the{Byron family.}The Byrons lived at Clayton Hall until 1620 when it was sold to{Humphrey Chetham, founder of Chetham's Hospital. {Renovation work is in progress}prior to opening to the public. Workmen said that they hoped to use some of the original beams in the renovation. We were also told of an old bell in the wooden turret in the south side of the hall. It is said to be one of 4 taken from from the old parish church of Manchester when rebuilt in the 15th century.
